definition:
A metric space $(X,d)$ is said to have the *disjoint disks property*
(DDP) if for every pair of continuous maps $f,g: B^2 \to X$ of the
closed $B^2$ into $X$ and every $\epsilon > 0$ there exist continuous
maps $f', g' : B^2 \to X$ such that $d(f,f') < \epsilon$ ,
$d(g,g') < \epsilon$ and $f'(B^2) \cap g'(B^2) = \varnothing$.
